popt4jlib.network

Class AsgnAuctionMT

  • java.lang.Object
    • popt4jlib.network.AsgnAuctionMT

  • public class AsgnAuctionMT
extends java.lang.Object
    Multi-threaded auction algorithm for the assignment problem. The algorithm is guaranteed to find the optimal solution of an n × n assignment problem, assuming a feasible solution exists, in a finite amount of time. It also detects infeasibility, so it always terminates in a finite amount of time, though the infeasibility detection is the "easy" method described by Bertsekas (1992), based on the value v_{ij} falling below a threshold, and may take some time before this happens. For a textbook treatment of this algorithm, see "Bertsekas, D. & Tsitsiklis, J. (1989) Parallel and Distributed Computation: Numerical Methods, Prentice-Hall." The detection of infeasibility is described in "Bertsekas, D. (1992): Auction Algorithms for Network Flow Problems: A Tutorial Introduction, Laboratory for Information and Decision Systems Technical Report LIDS-P-2108, MIT". The same text mentions the idea of spreading an individual person's bid computations across multiple processors when the number of persons bidding for objects is one or just a few. The implementation supports ε-scaling to avoid issues when the arc cost coefficients vary significantly, and there are large cost coefficients. Scaling is very important when solving large instances (with problem size 20000 or more) and with arc costs being in the order of 500 or more.

    Testing with sparse random assignment problems with problem size up to 50000 showed that the speedup obtained by using many threads is unfortunately very small, almost always less than 1.5, even when 4 or 8 threads are utilized.

    As a final notice, due to the sparse integer vector implementation used, the problem must be such that arc costs (value a person has for an object) can never be zero (as they are ignored, and the connection is not recorded). If needed, the user should add a constant to all the arc costs of their problem, so that no zero arc value appears, and then subtract the constant times the size of the problem from the final assignment value.

    Title: popt4jlib

    Description: A Parallel Meta-Heuristic Optimization Library in Java

    Copyright: Copyright (c) 2011-2018

    Company:

    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    Ioannis T. Christou

      runs in parallel the Auction algorithm for the Assignment problem, and returns a utils.PairObjDouble containing as object an int[] array containing the assignment of each user to an object, and the value of the assignment as the second argument of the pair.

    • Constructor Detail

      • AsgnAuctionMT

        public AsgnAuctionMT(int[][] userObjects,
                     int[][] aij,
                     java.util.HashMap params)
        sole public constructor accepts as arguments the set of objects that each user is interested in, and the value they get from each of them, if assigned to them.
        Parameters:
        userObjects - int[][] the ids of the objects each person is interested in
        aij - int[][] the values that each person gives to each object of interest
        params - HashMap should contain the key-value pair <"asgnauctionmt.numthreads",Integer num_threads>. May also contain the pair <"asgnauctionmt.runBidsParallelThreads", Integer val> with -1 default, indicating 8 threads to be used in parallel bidding per user.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - (unchecked) if there is an empty row in userObjects or a mismatch in the dimensions of any row in the first two arguments

      • AsgnAuctionMT

        public AsgnAuctionMT(int[][] userObjects,
                     int[][] aij,
                     double[] pj,
                     java.util.HashMap params)
        public constructor used in the epsilon-scaling version of the algorithm.
        Parameters:
        userObjects - int[][] the indices of the objects each user is interested in
        aij - int[][] the values that each user gives to each object of interest
        pj - double[] the ending object prices of the previous iteration, that will be doubled for this problem
        params - HashMap should contain the key-value pair <"asgnauctionmt.numthreads",Integer num_threads>. May also contain the pair <"asgnauctionmt.runBidsParallelThreads", Integer val> with -1 default, indicating no parallel bidding computation per specific user
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - (unchecked) if there is an empty row in userObjects or a mismatch in the dimensions of any row in the first two arguments

    • Method Detail

      • maximize

        public PairObjDouble maximize()
        runs in parallel the Auction algorithm for the Assignment problem, and returns a utils.PairObjDouble containing as object an int[] array containing the assignment of each user to an object, and the value of the assignment as the second argument of the pair.
        Returns:
        PairObjDouble

      • main

        public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
        invoke as java -cp <classpath> popt4jlib.network.AsgnAuctionMT <asgn_file> [use_epsilon_scaling?(false)] [num_threads(1)] [dbglvl(0)] [runBidsParallelThreads?(-1)] . The format of the asgn_file is the one described in the javadoc for utils.DataMgr.readIntSparseVectorsFromFile().
        Parameters:
        args - String[]
